required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Fetal Neurobehavior in Poly-drug Dependent Women

brief_summary.textblock: This project examines fetal neurobehavior and maternal physiology in poly-drug dependent women. This study also evaluates infant neonatal abstinence syndrome, infant neurobehavior and vagal tone in the post-partum period.

detailed_description.textblock: Little is known about the link between maternal physiology, fetal neurobehavior and neonatal abstinence syndrome in multiply drug-dependent women. Previous research by this group of investigators has found that the severity of neonatal abstinence syndrome in methadone exposed infants is related to maternal vagal tone changes in response to methadone during pregnancy. While previous research has focused on drug abstinent, methadone maintained women, most drug dependent pregnant women are poly-substance abusers who also use prescription psychiatric medications, alcohol and nicotine. This protocol seeks to further our understanding of the effects of multiple drugs on the fetus, including the co-variate effects of maternal psychological status. Infant neurobehavior and vagal tone will also be evaluated. This research will extend our knowledge of fetal neurobehavioral development and neonatal abstinence syndrome in a realistic population of poly-drug dependent women, potentially altering the way in which these women are evaluated and their infants monitored and treated for neonatal abstinence syndrome.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age 18-41
- Single intrauterine fetus
- Free of significant maternal or fetal significant health complications
Exclusion Criteria:
- Development of significant maternal or fetal health complications
- Significant maternal psychopathology that would preclude informed consent
- Unwilling or unable to receive methadone at prescribed times

facility.name: The Center for Addiction and Pregnancy

results_reference.citation: Jansson LM, Di Pietro JA, Elko A, Williams EL, Milio L, Velez M. Pregnancies exposed to methadone, methadone and other illicit substances, and poly-drugs without methadone: a comparison of fetal neurobehaviors and infant outcomes. Drug Alcohol Depend. 2012 May 1;122(3):213-9. doi: 10.1016/j.drugalcdep.2011.10.003. Epub 2011 Oct 29.

responsible_party.investigator_title: Associate Professor of Pediatrics Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine
